text: this is part two of our lesson on L in
this lesson we're going to practice
making L in the middle of words
let's begin by reviewing how we make the
L sound in general I told you in our
first lesson that the most important
thing is the position of our tongue the
tip of your tongue needs to touch the
heart bump behind your upper front teeth
and a drawing it looked like this upper
front teeth lower front teeth this is
that hard bump behind your upper front
teeth and this is the roof of your mouth
the tip of your tongue needs to touch
that hard bump behind your front teeth
that's the main point of contact now the
sides of your tongue are down so that
air can flow on both sides of your
tongue your lips are gently rounded and
you need to use your voice when l is
followed by another sound a vowel sound
you need to drop your tongue and let it
flow in to the next sound our examples
in the first lesson worth laughs lap the
tip of your tongue dropped to make the
next vowel sound lap laughs now we're
going to look at words where L has a vow
before it and a vowel after it for
example in the word alive
so you have two vowel sounds one before
and one after you say ah for alive make
the L with the tip of your tongue
against the bump and as you move into
I've you need to drop your tongue and
make the full I sound live live
let's try similar words
exercise 1 listen and repeat after me
alive smallest tallest olive
see link feeling
palace
calling falling polite valley chile
balloon yellow belong below pillow hello
now let's try some phrases listen and
repeat after me a yellow balloon the
smallest olive the tallest elephant the
valley below ceilings in the palace a
yellow pillow the smallest belly feeling
alive smelling olives a polite hello
now let's practice L when it's followed
by a consonant for example in the word
old old the important thing here is to
keep the tip of your tongue pressed
against this bump behind your upper
front teeth old old it only comes away
when you have to pronounce the D old but
to get that L sound
you must keep it pressed against that
bump and there should be vibration the
whole time from the old to the L and
finally into the D old it's important to
make the L long enough so that it's
heard if you try to say this word too
quickly people may not hear your L so
take the time to keep the tongue pressed
against the bump and really give sound
with your voice old again this is
practice sometimes it's best to
exaggerate so that you can teach your
mouth how to work in the way that's
needed sometimes this is a way that's
not done in your native language that's
why we need to exaggerate in time it
will feel more natural we'll also see L
followed by a consonant in words like
this mailman now mailman actually has
two syllables mailman we can divide it
right there mailman so L is followed by
a consonant but really it's the end of a
syllable the same thing happens here you
need to keep the tip of your tongue
pressed against the bump behind your
upper teeth mail man it only comes away
when you finally get into the second
syllable to make the M mail man so let's
now practice words that are similar to
old and mailman
exercise 3 listen and repeat after me
mailman dolphin healthy always railway
Holloway welcome bald belt felt wild
milk
help
helper
golfer wolf
oldest bald
cold folded field
